She sends the following message to her financial backers: “I am very grateful because you have opened the doors of my business for me; what a joy it is that there are people who help us to achieve our dreams”. Currently Hilda is applying for a new loan with which she will buy fabric, thread, buttons, and zippers. She plans to be successful because the end of the year is approaching and she will be prepared for it.

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, buttons, and zippers

loans.name: Juliett Paulina

texts.es: Juliett tiene 27 años de edad. Tiene dos negocios o actividades, comercio de ropa, calzado, perfumes, y cosméticos; y presta el servicio de cortes de cabello, peinados, blower, manicure, y pedicure. Vive en el municipio de Soledad, en el departamento del Atlántico, con su hijo de 4 años de edad; es mujer cabeza de familia. Desde el año 2003, es decir, hace 10 años aprendió el arte de negociar, vendiendo productos variados (ropa, calzado, perfumes) a familiares, amigos, vecinos y recomendados, a crédito y de contado. El oficio de peluquería, belleza, manicure y pedicure, lo aprendió desde hace 2 años, ofreciendo este servicio en su casa y a domicilio. Diariamente le dedica 8 horas a sus actividades de comercio y servicio. Compra a crédito y de contado, los productos que vende y los insumos que usa en el servicio de belleza, en almacenes mayoristas. Este es su primer credikiva con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, el cual lo aplicará en la compra de tratamientos de belleza, ropa, calzado, colonias, perfumes, cremas y cosméticos, para atender los pedidos  de sus clientes y brindarles un mejor servicio; esto con el objetivo de aumentar sus ingresos y utilidades. Una de sus metas con la inversión de los próximos créditos es la de ir fortaleciendo su negocio de belleza con equipos y herramientas.
texts.en:
Juliett is 27 years old and has two businesses: selling clothing, footwear, perfumes and cosmetics, and providing a service cutting hair, styling hair, blow-drying hair and doing manicures and pedicures.  She lives in the town of Soledad, in Atlántico department, with her 4-year-old son.  She is a single mother.

In 2003, that is to say 10 years ago, Juliett learned the art of buying a range of products (clothing, footwear and perfume) and selling them to family members, friends, neighbors and people she has been recommended to.  She makes her sales on credit and for cash.  She learned the hairdressing, beauty, manicure and pedicure trade two years ago and provides these services both in her own home and in other people's.  She works eight hours a day in her commercial and service-sector businesses.  She buys the products that she sells and the supplies that she uses in her beauty business, both on credit and for cash, from wholesalers.

This is Juliett's first loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she will use it to buy beauty treatments, clothing, footwear, cologne, perfume, creams and cosmetics so that she can fill her customers' orders and offer them a better service.  This will help her to increase her income and profits.  One of Juliett's goals for investing her future loans is to continue strengthening her beauty business by purchasing equipment and tools.

loans.use: to buy beauty treatments, clothing, footwear, cologne, perfume, creams and cosmetics

loans.name: Marie Costa

texts.en:
Marie Costa is 33 years old; she is married to a businessman. 

She sells foodstuffs, and has been in this business for the past four years. 

With the loan, Marie Costa would like to add more rice, sweet potatoes, and cassava to sell. 

She plans to save the profits from the business.

loans.use: To buy more sweet potatoes, rice, and cassava to sell.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is 34 years old, married and lives in Gbarnga in Liberia. Gbarnga is located in the centre of Liberia, in Bong County. The majority of people there are employed as farmers, cultivating crops such as rice, palm oil, and cassava. 

Theresa went to school, and finished grade 12. Her husband is a teacher, and she has three children between the ages of 11 and 19.  

She has had a table business for the past four years, and sells slippers.  She works at her business nine hours a day, and she transports her goods to her business by bus. The biggest challenge she faces in her business is insufficient goods on her table.
 
She wants to buy more slippers to sell with the proceeds from the loan.  Theresa describes herself as a hardworking woman; she started her business with money from her mother. 

In the future, she wants to own a house.  Theresa is proud of her business because she gets money everyday from her business. 
 
She wants to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to buy more slippers to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet  is married, with four children; three of her children go to school.  She also takes care of an additional family member, her brother.  She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes rent and school fees.

Janet has a business of selling used clothes, and has been in this business for ten years. She generates additional income through poultry farming.  She works from home, and at times moves door-to-door selling used clothes.  She works six days a week and sells on a retail basis only.  

She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more blouses and skirts.  Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality.  She is aspires to get a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more used blouses and skirts to sell.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 34 years old, married and lives in Gbarnga in Liberia. Gbarnga is located in the centre of Liberia in Bong County. The majority of the people are employed as farmers, cultivating crops such as rice, palm oil, and cassava. 

Beatrice went to school and finished grade 12.  Her husband is a teacher, and she has a nine-year-old child at home who goes to school. 
 
She has had a table business for the past four years, selling rice, oil, pepper, etc.  She works at her business nine hours a day, and she transports her goods to her business by bus. The biggest challenge she faces in her business is insufficient inventory on her table.  

With the proceeds from the loan, she wants to buy rice, oil, pepper, etc.  She describes herself as a hardworking woman; she started her business with money from her mother. She is proud of her business because she gets money for her expenses.

In the future, Beatrice wants to own a house.    

She wants to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, pepper, etc.

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en: Donatha is 26 years old. She sells vegetables and has been in the business for one year. With the loan, she would like to buy more vegetables for resale. She plans to use the profits to add to her savings.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Weyatta

texts.en:
Meet 37-year-old Weyatta from Kandeh town Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married and has four children. Three of her children are going to school.  In 2005, Weyatta established her cosmetic business. She began her business because she needs to generate income to take care of herself and her family. She works at the business every day from morning to night. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation of goods.

Weyatta requires a loan in order to purchase a variety of cosmetics to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and improve her standard of living. In the future, Weyatta plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of cosmetics

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive is 26 years old. She is married with one child. Her husband works as a house builder. Olive sells different items in her boutique for which she has been running for the past four years. With the loan, she would like to buy more sugar, cooking oil and soap for sale. The profits from the business will be used to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, cooking oil and soap for sale.

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Timothy lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is the training ground for many of Kenya's Olympic runners. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business. He has no children and has been doing this work for three years. 

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: “It generates income easily. I understand the challenges.” His biggest challenge is “diseases that hinder milk production.”  Animals on the farm have been given the names of “Lelmet, Baraka, and Juhudi".

Timothy was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied, “Deals with farmers and loans out finances to generate more income.” This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, and replied, “Savings culture is important. Record-keeping is essential. Loan is issued for small-scale farmers.”

His highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked, “How will this loan benefit (your) family?”, Timothy replied, “Increased income.”

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Timothy owns a cow and poultry, but does not own a pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile.  Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, or DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Meet 39-year-old Alice from Kandeh town Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married with five children, two of which are going to school.  

In 2005, Alice established her palm oil business. She began her business because she needed to generate income to take care of herself and her family. She works at the business every day from morning to night.  She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and transportation.

Alice requires a loan to purchase palm oil, gari (a starchy vegetable), and general stock. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. 

In the future, Alice plans to take her business to a higher level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil, gari and general stock.

loans.name: Sylvie

texts.en:
Sylvie is 26 years old; she sells scraps, and her husband works as a mechanic. They have two children ages three and seven. 

She wants the loan to buy more scraps to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy a house.

loans.use: To buy more scraps to sell.

loans.name: Liliane

texts.en: Liliane is aged 31. She is married with three children. Her husband works as a technician. She wants the loan to buy more foodstuffs such as potatoes and bananas for sale. The profits from the business will be used to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more  potatoes and bananas for sale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Meet 34-year-old Florence from Kandeh town Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children. Three of her children are going to school.  In 2005, Florence established her cosmetics business. She began her business because she needs to generate income to take care of herself and her family. She works at the business every day from morning to night.  She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and transportation.

Florence requires a loan in order to purchase a variety of cosmetics to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, Florence plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of cosmetics to expand her business.

loans.name: Venuste

texts.en: Venuste is 27 years old. He is single and sells handbags for ladies. He has been in the business for three years. With the loan, he wants to add more handbags for sale. The profits from the business will be used to put aside more savings.

loans.use: To buy more handbags for sale.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica lives outside of Maphombe, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, near Tanzania. Inconsistent rains, especially recently, have made farming difficult, and the poverty rates in the county are above the Kenyan average. Beekeeping is somewhat new to Kwale, but the passion fruit farms and mangrove forests throughout the area provide excellent sources of nectar for bee colonies. Many farmers in the area have expressed excitement at the prospect of owning their own hives, and having a second source of income from their honey to help care for their families.  

Veronica is married, and has seven children. Both she and her husband have been farming for twelve years and are currently growing oranges on their land. She is excited to start beekeeping because it will give her a source of high-quality, natural honey, which she enjoys eating. 

This is Veronica's first loan and she plans to use the income generated by her hives to make some improvements around her farm. In the future, Veronica hopes to save up enough money to build a new family house.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
This loan will help Esther purchase equipment for her home-based business. 

Esther grew up in the Dominican Republic and has lived in the United States for 29 years. She is a college graduate in business administration, former preschool teacher, and above all, a dedicated mother to her son and daughter.  

Her business, Sky Sunshine Daycare, has been in operation for over three years. In particular, she focuses on children from birth to five years of age. She prides herself on being able to provide working parents with a professional and encouraging environment for their children during the day. 

Encouraged by the growing demand for her services, Esther reached out to Accion East and Online to help purchase a new computer, a desk, a television and a sink. She also hopes to invest in radio advertising. Her vision for the future is to expand her business across the United States, improve the quality of life for her family, and help the community and children at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital.

loans.use: to purchase a computer, desk, television, and sink for her business

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah lives close to Ukunda, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though places like Ukunda along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives.

Elijah is married and has two children. His wife works as a businesswoman, while Elijah tends to their land: he is currently nurturing a tree plantation on their property. He is excited to start beekeeping because it represents a good income source, and he is also interested in receiving some training in beekeeping. 

This is Elijah's first loan, and he plans to use the income generated by his beehives to help educate his children. Elijah's hope for the future is to continue to be able to use honey revenue to put his children through school.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 28-year-old Fatmata from Kandeh town Bo. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 4 years and 15 years. Two of her children are currently attending school. 

Fatmata runs a general stock business; she sells soft drinks, mayonnaise, biscuits and sweets. She has been running this business for 15 years. She works at the business throughout the week and 10 hours per day. Fatmata says that at present her business is doing well.

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to purchase soft drinks, mayonnaise, biscuits and sweets for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise even more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, mayonnaise, biscuits and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes lives and works outside of Magodi, in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast near the border of Tanzania. While beekeeping has not historically been a major activity in the region, the mangrove swamps closer to the coast and large passion fruit farms inland provide bees with robust sources of nectar. Though most farmers in the area are new to beekeeping, many are very enthusiastic about keeping bees. 

Agnes is married, and has six children. Both she and her husband farm, and are currently growing maize on their land. She is excited to start beekeeping because the income from honey will be helpful, and she is also interested in learning about bees. 

This is Agnes' first loan, and she plans to use the proceeds to help build an addition to her home. In the future, she hopes to expand her apiary and reach a "commercial level" of production.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen, de 46 años es una mujer sencilla. Vive en compañía de su esposo Juvenal y sus 5 hijos. A los que cuida en la casa que compró hace 20 años. Carmen se dedica a la ganadería, pues vive en una zona rica en vegetación y por años sus padres le enseñaron las mejores técnicas de crianza y producción de leche. En la actualidad esta es su principal actividad económica. Posee 5 vacas y 14 ovejas de las cuales cuida a todas con mucho esmero y empeño, pues diariamente elabora queso, con la leche que producen. Ahora desea seguir con el mejoramiento de sus animales, pues su secreto se centra en alimentarlos con pasto natural, comida concentrada, desparasitarlos y chequear su buena producción de leche. Este es su cuarto crédito con KIVA y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero que recibe para seguir adelante, razón por la cual se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. Carmen, invertirá los S/.300 soles en la compra de ovejas, para aumentar su ganado
texts.en: Carmen is 46 years old. She is a humble woman. She lives with her husband  Juvenal and their 5 children. She cares for them in a house she bought 20 years ago. Carmen works with livestock. She lives in an area with rich vegetation and for years her parents taught her the best practices for raising livestock and producing milk. Right now, this is her main economic activity. She owns 5 cows and 14 sheep that she cares for with a lot of hard work and dedication. She makes cheese every day with the milk they produce. Now she wants to continue improving her animals, because her secret is feeding them with natural grass and feed concentrate, deworming them and checking to see if they have good milk production. This is her fourth loan with Kiva and she is grateful for the financial support she is receiving to get ahead. That is why she is committed to making her payments on time. Carmen will invest the   S/.300 soles in buying sheep, to increase her livestock.

loans.use: to buy sheep.

loans.name: Neneh

texts.en: Meet Neneh, who is in her late thirties, from Kandeh town in Sierra Leone. She is married and has six children between the ages of 6 years and 20. In 1995, Neneh established her palm oil business. She began her business because she needed to create a source of income to support her children. She works at the business eight hours per day and six days per week. She says that her business is growing well. Neneh needs a loan to buy more palm oil for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, Neneh plans to expand her business even more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 36-year-old Fatmata from Kandeh town in Sierra Leone. She is married with one child aged   15 years.  In 2008, Fatmata established her palm oil business. She began her business because she needed to create a source of income to support her child. She works at the business 10 hours per day and six days per week.  She says that her business is growing well.   

Fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase more palm oil for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, Fatmata plans to expand her business more than ever. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Regun

texts.en:
Regun lives and works in a small town in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast, and borders Tanzania to the south. Inconsistent rainfalls make farming difficult and contribute to the area's high poverty rates. Despite the unreliable rainfall, bees in the region have two excellent sources of food, from wild mangrove forest and local passion fruit plantations. Beekeeping is relatively new to the area, but many farmers are very interested in owning hives. 

Regun is unmarried and has been farming for six years. He is currently growing passion fruit on his land. He is excited to start beekeeping because he likes learning about bees, and he is also happy to have a secondary income source from honey. 

This is Regun's first loan, and he plans to use the money generated from his hives to help pay school fees. Regun's hope for the future is to work for Honey Care, inspecting beehives as a Hive Technician.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.es: Rosalia nació en la ciudad Puno y tiene 39 años de edad, ella vive en la hermosa ciudad de Pilcopata junto con sus seis hijos y son muy felices, ella es madre soltera pues a pesar de la adversidad saca adelante a sus hijos con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación pues su actividad económica principal es la venta de desayunos de forma ambulatoria como por ejemplo jugos de manzana, quinua, maca, mates, pan con queso, pan con palta, tortas y pasteles. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Kusacha de Pilcopata” y esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos como manzanas, quinua, leche, panes, queso, palta, maca y así aumentar su capital de trabajo en este rubro. Agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (El poblado de Pilcopata se destaca por el comercio de productos de la selva, así como servicios de alojamiento y restaurantes. Punto de ingreso al Parque Nacional del Manu.)
texts.en:
Rosalia was born in the city of Puno. She is 39 years old and lives in the beautiful city of Pilcopata with her six children and they are very happy. She is a single mother and so despite adversity she is bringing up her children through struggles and dedication. 

Her main financial activity is selling breakfast as a traveling vendor, for example apple juice, quinoa, maca (relative of the radish) mate (traditional beverage) bread with cheese, bread with avocados, cakes and pastries. She has been working in this business for several years and is doing well thanks to the effort she puts into her work. 

She belongs to the communal bank Kusacha de Pilcopata and at this time she is requesting a loan to buy more supplies such as apples, quinoa, milk, breads, cheese, avocados, and maca in order to increase her working capital in this field. She is grateful and appreciates the loan agreeing to comply with the monthly payments responsibly.

The village of Pilcopata is known for its trade in forest products, as well as for accommodations and restaurants. It is the point of entry to the Manu National Park.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as apples, quinoa, milk, breads, cheese, avocados and maca.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 29-year-old Isata from Kandeh town Bo. She is married with two children, 3 years and 7 years old. She also takes care of her mother. 

Isata runs a palm oil business; she sells palm oil, nut oil, and coconut oil. She has been running this business for seven years. She walks to her business 5 miles each way to reach to her area of operation.  She does not have any source of income except her business.   She says despite the hardship of lacking a vehicle, she is hardworking with the desire to become a successful businesswoman and educate her children.   

Isata has requested a loan in order to purchase local food including palm oil, nut oil, and coconut oil. The extra income from this loan will allow her to have a permanent business location and improve her living conditions. In the future, she plans to open a big food store. She thanks you for your support

loans.use: to purchase local food including palm oil, nut oil, and coconut oil.

loans.name: Komang

texts.en:
Komang is a Balinese artisan who specializes in handcrafted sterling silver jewelry. He would like to invest in the purchase of silver and gemstones to increase production.

Komang has been selling through NOVICA since 2002. This is his story:

"At first I did not show any interest in the creation of silver jewelry and instead learned to carve wood. However, during secondary school, I eventually became drawn to the creation of fine silver jewelry. Due to harsh economic circumstances, I had to work after school. I walked far everyday to Celuk, a village renowned for its silver and gold jewelry where I began to acquire the elements of my craft.

"Thanks to all of you for your support and for offering me this microcredit, which will make it easier for me to purchase the materials I need. I wish to promote my collections so that many more people can see them, and hopefully my sales will increase over last year. If that happens, it will really help us here. Thanks and God bless you."

Use the link below to view Komang's handcrafted jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/3065

loans.use: to purchase silver and gemstones to increase production

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John lives in a small town in Kwale County. Kwale County is located on the Kenyan coast, near Tanzania. Inconsistent rains, especially recently, have made farming difficult, and the poverty rates in the county are above the Kenyan average. Beekeeping is somewhat new to Kwale, but the passion fruit farms and mangrove forests throughout the area provide excellent sources of nectar for bee colonies. Many farmers in the area have expressed excitement at the prospect of owning their own hives and having a second source of income from their honey to help care for their families.  

John is married and has two children. His wife currently works in tailoring, and John farms their land and engages in some business, including selling pineapples he grows and rearing dairy goats. He is very excited to start beekeeping, as the bees will facilitate crop pollination, improving production.

This is John's first loan, and he plans to use the income generated from his beehives to make some improvements to the house where he keeps his dairy goats. In the future, John hopes to increase his apiary to house 20 hives.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta is a businesswoman who lives in Tugas, Baliangao. She is 35 years old. She is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Julieta has a shop that sells assorted groceries and snacks. She has been in this business for 4 years earning a monthly income of 3600 PHP. Julieta has requested a loan to purchase one motorcycle unit. Julieta has been a CUMI member of Paglaum MPC since 2011.

loans.use: To purchase 1 motorcycle unit for her business.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 29-year-old Fatmata. She is single and has no children.  In 2007, Fatmata established her business selling cups, plates, sets of dishes, and lunch bowls. She started her business because she wanted to be gainfully employed as she does go to school. Her business is located in the city center and her main customers are the general public. Her business operates 6 days a week, 10 hours a day, and she earns SLL 1,000,000 every month.

Fatmata would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000 in order to buy sets of dishes, plates, and lunch packs. She hopes that this loan will help her increase her profits by SLL 750,000. In the future, Fatmata plans to rent a big shop so that she can sell items wholesale. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for plates, dishes, and lunch bowls

loans.name: Rochelle's Group

texts.en: Rochelle is 31 years old and lives in Bita-ug, Enrique Villanueva, Siquijor. She is married and has two children. One of her children attends school, while the other is still an infant. Rochelle has been engaged in a fishing business for almost six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP each month doing this work. She has requested a loan to purchase additional fishing equipment. In the future, Rochelle hopes to expand her business with this institution.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment such as net and styrofoam

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha is a single mother with one child, who doesn’t go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (two brothers). She has a business selling fresh fruits and has been in this business for four years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more boxes of fresh mangoes, paw-paws and oranges. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. She works at the market for seven days every week. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to grow some of the fruit and also to become a wholesaler of fruits. She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medications.

loans.use: to buy more boxes of fruit, such as mangoes, pawpaws and oranges, for resale.

loans.name: Isidoro

texts.en:
Isidoro is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in hand-loomed alpaca throws, apparel and accessories. He would like to invest in the purchase of larger quantities of alpaca yarn to increase production.

Isidoro has been selling through NOVICA since 2006. This is his story:

"I was forced to migrate in the 1970s when terrorist activities swept this region. I found a job as janitor in a textile factory. I was completely fascinated! At night, when everyone had gone, I began to experiment with the looms. The manager caught me and said I should start by learning how to assemble a loom. That was the beginning of a vocation, a great gift that I have now also passed on to my children.

"I would like to express to all of you my sincere gratitude for this micro-credit. We want to build up our stock of materials and finished products. Please receive a heartfelt hug and thanks all the way from Peru!" 

Use the link below to view Isidoro's alpaca throws, apparel and accessories on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/5709

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of larger quantities of alpaca yarn to increase production.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice B. is 26 years old and lives in the Gbarnga area. She’s single with two children, age 8 and 6; they live at home and attend school. For the past two years, she has been running a shop in the community. 

Beatrice has requested this loan to purchase more used clothes in other to have sufficient goods for her customers. The problem she’s faced with is that her customers sometimes take the goods on credit and don’t pay. She started this business by selling cool water in a wheelbarrow and learned this from friends. What she likes about this business is that she makes new friends every day. Having money in her home makes her proud of her business. In the near future, she wants to open another shop.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes in other to have sufficient goods for her customers.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This borrower is 32-year-old Sarah from Kandeh town Bo. She is married and has four children between the ages of 4 and 12. Three of her children are attending school. Sarah runs a palm oil business, selling items such as palm oil, paper and okra. She has been running this business for two years. She works at the business ten hours per day and seven days per week. Sarah says that the main challenges to her business are that sometime purchasing power is very low, that she doesn’t have many items on her table and that she lacks funds to expand her business. Sarah has applied for a loan in order to buy food items, including rice, onions, cooking seasonings and coconut oil . The extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business even more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase food items to sell, including rice, onions, cooking seasoning and coconut oil.

loans.name: Jannsetta

texts.en:
This is Jannnsetta from Liberia. She lives in Gbarnga, the capital city of Bong County, which is located in the center of the country. The majority of people here are farmers growing crops such as rice, palm oil and cassava. 

She is 35 years old and married with 4 children. Her oldest child is 13 and her youngest child is 6. All of them are currently living at home and going to school.  

Jannsetta has owned her own business selling used clothes for the past 3 years. She will use the loan proceeds to purchase used clothes. On average, she works 9 hours at her business everyday. She started her business by selling for her friends. She transports her merchandise by bus. She cites her small income as her biggest challenge. Her favorite part of her business is the buying. In the future, she would like to build a house.  

She is grateful for your support!

loans.use: to purchase used clothes.

loans.name: Tiarge

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 41-year-old Tiarge from Kandeh town Bo. She is married and has seven children. Two of children are currently attending school. Tiarge runs a food stand where she sells rice, pepper and cooking seasonings. She has been running this business for 20 years. She works at the business throughout the week, ten hours per day. Tiarge says that at present her business is doing well. Tiarge has applied for a loan in order to buy cooking oil, rice and cooking seasonings for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children’s school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise even more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, rice and cooking seasonings for resale.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 36-year-old Baby from Kandeh town Bo. She is married with 7 children between the ages of 5 and 20. Four of her children are currently attending school. 

Baby runs a food stand; she sells rice, flour, and cooking seasonings. She has been running this business for 17 years. She works at the business throughout the week for 10 hours per day. Baby says that at present her business is doing well.

Baby has requested a loan to purchase cooking oil, rice and flour for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, rice and flour to resell.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
Ana Maria is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in handcrafted copper and bronze masks and vases. She needs to buy copper and bronze to continue crafting her designs.

Ana Maria has been selling through NOVICA since 2001. This is her story:

"For 24 years I have dedicated myself to metalwork in the city where I married. My husband is an able jeweler from whom I learned the art of working with silver and plaques. Today we have a small family workshop in which my children are also involved, and we work together with dedication, constantly developing new products. In my work I seek to recover the folklore and joy of the Andean people.

"I'd like to send a big hug and kiss to those of you across the miles who are funding this micro-credit. Many thanks for supporting my work. I want so much to grow as a person and as an artisan!"

Use the link below to view Ana Maria's copper masks and vases on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/2843

loans.use: to buy copper and bronze to continue crafting her designs.

loans.name: Victoria De La Fe 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en: Margalet is the coordinator of her group, Victoria de la Fe 1, 2 and 3 (Victory of Faith), located in a village where most of the citizens are Haitians. She lives in a modest home with her two children. With her efforts, she can make extra income and provide for her family. She enjoys going to work and taking care of her children. Margalet is excited to be taking out her third loan from Esperanza. She runs a business selling cosmetic products. She has had her business for nearly two years. She began her business by selling miscellaneous products that she bought with her first loan. Margaret is planning to use this new loan to invest in her business by buying more cosmetics. She will reinvest the profits in her business by purchasing more products and expanding her business, offering more options and gaining new clients. Margalet dreams of becoming someone with a very large business; she wants to have a general store. She represents her group and many Haitians who have emigrated to the Dominican Republic to improve their lives. In this group are 15 Haitian families, a sample of those fighting to overcome the Haiti crisis. Thanks to you for supporting this group.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products for her business.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is married with 2 children. She is 59 years old and lives in Mandih, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines.

Julieta is a farmer who grows rice and corn to earn a living. She has been doing this for 19 years. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and to maintain her farming machinery.

Julieta has been a member of PMPC for almost 6 years. In the future, she hopes to have a successful business and to live happily with her family in good living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

location.town: Sindangan - Mandih, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Faidah

texts.en: Farida is married and has five children, only one of whom goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren). She has business selling charcoal and has been in this business for two years. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She generates additional income by selling tomatoes, onions and banana leaves. She works in the market six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis only. Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to build her own house. She lives in a rented house, and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 47 years old and lives in Maras, Sindangan, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is married with 10 children.

Victoria works in the fish industry and sells dried fish for a living. She has been doing this for 25 years. She has requested a loan to purchase fishing materials.

Victoria has been a member of PMPC for almost six years. In the future, Victoria hopes to build a piggery.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials.

location.town: Sindangan - Maras, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en: Leonila is 71 years old and lives in Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has 12 children. Leonila is engaged in a business making nipa huts (traditional house in the Philippines). She earns approximately 4,000 PHP each month doing this work. She has requested a loan to purchase additional nipa leaves for making and selling nipa huts. Leonila has been a member of PMPC for almost eight years. In the future, Leonila hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase nipa leaves

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie is married and has one child who attends school. Elsie is 53 years old and lives in Bita-ug, Enrique Villanueva, Siquijor. She is engaged in farming, and has been doing this for 20 years to support her family's daily needs. She has requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to purchase additional farm supplies. Elsie has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Elsie hopes to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Doña Celia es una mujer muy alegre, siempre contando chistes. A todo le encuentra el lado amable y divertido,  pero también es una persona muy trabajadora. Ella vive en una comunidad muy desarrollada que está dividida por manzanas (blocks) los habitantes de la comunidad son todos muy amables, la mayoría de ellos se dedica la cultivo de maíz, otros tienen negocios diferentes como comercios. 

Doña Celia tiene 39 años de edad está casada desde hace 19 años con el señor Francisco juntos han formado una familia con tres niños dos ellos van a la escuela, la señora Celia se dedica al cultivo de hongos setas desde hace ocho años Doña Celia Comento “Me gusto cultivar mis hongos porque mi mama se dedicaba al cultivo de champiñones, era un negocio muy bueno entonces fue como decidí iniciar con el cultivo de los hongos setas aunque es un negocio donde se requiere mucho trabajo me gusta mucho” Esta vez está solicitando un crédito para comprar cincuenta piezas de bolsas incubadoras para el cultivo de sus hongos,  su crédito le ayudará a comprar sus bolsas que son un poco caras. Doña Celia tomo algunos cursos para saber cómo mejorar el cultivo de sus hongos platica un poco de como los prepara. Primero necesita una tonelada de zacate picado el mismo zacate lo remoja en agua tiene que estar bien remojado, para ver si tiene el 70% de agua lo extiende muy bien y si le sale agua es porque tiene el agua que necesita. Después se junta todo como un colchón se tapa muy bien con un plástico negro esta preparación se deja reposar un día completo, al tercer día se cambia de lugar y también se tapa perfectamente, al séptimo día el zacate se esteriliza a baño María, este producto se deja en botes reposando para que al siguiente día se pueda sembrar en las bolsas incubadoras en ellas se pone zacate estas bolsas tienen que pesar 14 kilos, se dejan reposando 15 días, para después pasarlas al invernadero este proceso se le conoce como producción y finalmente solo espera para que los hongos inicien a brotar de la bolsa. Y es cuando Doña Celia cada tercer día tiene que cosechar sus hongos Zetas para sacarlos a la venta, Todos los días se tiene que levantar a las cuatro de la mañana para cosecharlos y así recién cortados los lleva al mercado para ofrecerlos a la plaza, Doña Celia dice que tiene ya clientas seguras, en el negocio le va muy bien sabe muy el proceso la única dificultad que presenta es cuando las bolsas incubadoras inician a mancharse de un color café esto significan malas noticias porque en esa bolsa no saldrán hongos aunque para Doña Celia significan perdidas de ganancias e inversión pero esto no la limita para tener muy presente su meta, la señora Celia sueña con tener más invernaderos y producir más hongos para aumentar sus ganancias y así ayudar con los gastos de educación de sus tres niños.
texts.en:
Celia is a very cheerful woman, always telling jokes. She finds the kind and funny side to everything, but she is also a very hardworking person. She lives in a very developed community that is divided into blocks. The residents of the community are friendly. Most of them grow corn and others have different businesses, such as stores.  

Celia is 39 years old. She has been married for 19 years to Francisco. Together they have made a family with three children. Two of them go to elementary school. Celia has grown seta mushrooms for 8 years. Celia remarked “I like to grow my seta mushrooms because my mother grew mushrooms. It was a very good business, so that was how I decided to start growing seta mushrooms. Although it is a business that requires a lot of work, I like it a lot." This time, she is asking for a loan to buy fifty units of incubator bags to buy the mushrooms. The loan will help her buy the bags, as they are a little expensive. Celia took some courses to learn how to improve at growing mushrooms. She talked a little about how she prepares them. First, she needs a ton of chopped grass. She wets the grass in water. It has to be really wet. If it is 70% water it expands well and if water is dripping it means it has all the water it needs. She pushes it all together like a mattress and covers it really well with a black tarp. She lets this sit for an entire day. The third day she moves it and covers it well again. The seventh day the grass is sterilized with steam. The result is put into containers until the next day, when it can be put into the incubator bags. The grass in the bags has to weigh 14 kilos. They are left for 15 days and then put in a green house. This process is known as the production, and finally she just has to wait for the mushrooms to start to sprout from the bag. Then Celia has to harvest the seta mushrooms every third day to sell them. Every day, she has to get up at four in the morning to harvest them and take them freshly cut to the market to sell them in the plaza. Celia says that she already has regular customers. The business is going very well for her and she knows the process very well. The only problem she has is when the incubator bags start to get a brown color. That is bad news because no mushrooms will come out of that bag. Although this means a loss of profit and investment for Celia, it doesn't limit her because she is focused on her goal. Celia dreams of having more greenhouses and producing more mushrooms to increase her profits and help pay for the education of her three children.

loans.use: to buy incubator bags to grow her seta mushrooms.

location.town: San Juan de las Manzanas, Ixtlahuaca

loans.name: 1Ero De Mayo Group

texts.es:
1Ero de Mayo es el nombre grupo integrado por 8 personas, estas personas se reunieron para formar un grupo ya que son vecinos y tienen algo en común una actividad económica y la ilusión de hacerlo crecer para brindar a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida.
Doña Braulia es uno de los integrantes de este grupo, ella tiene la edad de 50 años, solo estudio la primaria y es soltera actualmente solo tiene un hijo de 12 años que asiste a la primaria.
Ella platica que hace mas de 26 años se dedico al comercio porque siempre le ha gustado la venta y es un negocio rentable que deja buenas ganancias. Ella inicio cuando tenia 24 años con una venta de ropa para dama y caballero y a partir de esta actividad ha sacado adelante a sus hijos, hace un poco mas de un año le nació la idea de iniciar a vender abarrotes en su hogar así que construyo un pequeño local en su hogar en el cual tiene ubicación en su pequeña tienda.

Como no tiene mucho tiempo con su negocio poco a poco lo he surtido con variedad de productos pero aun le hace mucha falta, así que ha solicitado este crédito a VisioFund  para comprar arroz, frijol, aceite, productos enlatados, galletas, dulces, frituras, refrescos, jugos, sopa, jabón, papel de baño  para resurtir su negocio.
A futuro le gustaría que su negocio creciera mas y convertirlo en un pequeño  súper.
Este grupo agradece la oportunidad de recibir un crédito de Kiva.

Los demás integrantes de este grupo son:

Adela venta de zapatos
Luis venta de productos naturistas 
Estela venta de bolsas y cinturones 
Alejo venta de abarrotes
Rosa venta de ropa 
Mónica venta de antojitos 
Selene venta de ropa
texts.en:
This group is called 1Ero de Mayo and is made up of 8 people. These people came together to form a group as they are neighbors and they have in common business enterprises and the enthusiasm to make them prosper in order to give their families a better quality of life.

Braulia is one of the members of this group. She is 50 years old. She only studied through primary and currently she has a 12 year old son attending elementary school.

She says she has more than 26 years in the business because she likes to sell and it is a profitable business that leaves good earnings. She began when she was 24 years old selling clothes for ladies and men and through this business she brought up her children. A little more than a year ago she had the idea of selling groceries at her home and so established a place in her home where she could have her little store.

As she has not been in this business long, little by little she has purchased a variety of products but she still needs much more. So she is requesting a loan from VisioFund in order to buy rice, beans, oil, canned products, cookies, sweets, chips, soda, juices, soup, soap, and toilet paper to stock her business.

In the future she would like her business to expand and turn it into a mini-mart. 

This group is grateful for the opportunity to receive Kiva loans.

The other members of the group are:

Adela who sells shoes
Luis who sells natural products
Estela who sells bags and belts
Alejo who sells groceries
Rosa who sells clothing
Mónica who sells snacks
Selene who sells clothing

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, oil, canned products, cookies, sweets, chips, sodas, juices, soup, soap, and toilet paper

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 30-year-old Fatmata from Kandeh town Bo, in the southern area of Sierra Leone. She is married and has three children between the ages of 3 and 12. Her children are attending school. Fatmata runs a home-products business. She sells a variety of home products, such as food containers, bowls and buckets. She has been running this business for the past nine years. She works at the business throughout the week, ten hours per day. She says that her business is doing well and her customers increasing. Fatmata has applied for a loan in order to buy more stock, such as food containers, bowls and buckets. The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy items to sell, such as food containers, bowls and buckets.

loans.name: Pak's Group

texts.en:
Pak is 58 years old and widowed. She lives with her family in a rural area located in the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. She has ten children, two of whom are dependents and still in school. Rice farming is the only source of her family’s income and Pak has been a farmer for sixteen years. Currently, she earns approximately 23,000 KHR each day and is able to save about 10,000 KHR each day for her future needs.
 
Pak is the leader of a three-member loan group which has been with VisionFund for two cycles. She will use her portion of the loan to buy rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes to increase her current business to earn a larger income which will help her to make a better living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds for her farm

loans.name: Makiatu

texts.en:
This is 44-year-old Makiatu. She is married and has 4 children, aged 24, 18, 16, and 9 years. In 2008, Makiatu established a business selling skirts, jeans, blouses, and shoes. She began her business because she wants to support her husband in seeing that their children attain their educations to the fullest and to help financially in taking care of some problems at home. She operates her business 6 days a week, 12 hours a day, and she earns SLL 1,200,000 every month. 

Makiatu would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000 in order to add to her business capital so that she can buy more stock and realize more profit. She hopes that this loan will increase her profit by SLL 900,000. In the future, Makiatu plans to rent a shop at the main market. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for skirts, jeans, blouses, and other clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for more clothing

loans.name: Marian

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Marian. She is married and has two children, aged 14 and 11 years. In 1995, Marian established her slippers and sandals business. She began her business because she wanted to assist her husband with the upbringing of her children. Her business is located at the city centre and her main customers are the general public. She opens seven days a week and 10 hours a day. She earns 1,000,000 SLL (Sierra Leone leones) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Marian requires a loan in order to buy more cartons of slippers and sandals. She hopes that this loan will help to increase her profit approximately 700,000 SLL. In the future, Marian plans to be a distributor for one of the plastic industries that are operating in the country. She is very reliable. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for more plastic shoes.

loans.name: Bebe Joy

texts.en:
Bebe Joy, 26, is married with 2 children. She lives in Poblacion, Ramon Magsaysay Zamboanga Del Sur. Bebe Joy sells different kinds of spare parts to earn a living and has had this business for 2 years. Each month, she earns 30,000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for more stocks of her spare parts.

Bebe Joy has been a member of Paglaum MPC for almost 9 months. In the future, Bebe Joy hopes to expand her business and earn more to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to pay for stocks of spare parts.

loans.name: Dince

texts.en:
Dince, 37, is married to Marsel, 50. They’re blessed with four children: Yaya, 18, who is in college; Angel, 13, who is in her third year of Junior High School; Ofan, 10, who is in her fifth year of Elementary School; and Yolanda, 2. 

Dince has been running a kiosk for almost 6 months. It is a small kiosk at her home. She sells basic items such as cooking oil, coffee, salt, cereal, snacks, and candies for children. The income she earns from the business enables her to help her husband to cover her family's daily needs. 

Currently, Dince dreams of improving her business by adding more stock to her kiosk, but she does not have the capital to do so. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 12,500,000 IDR from TLM. This loan will help her to buy more stock, such as sugar, rice, biscuits, cigarettes and soft drinks. She also wants to buy 2 display cabinets and a refrigerator. Dince is expecting that TLM will approve her loan application.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory, 2 display cabinets and a refrigerator for her kiosk.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en: Felix is a married farmer who lives in Balintawak, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. He sells copra and bananas that he produces on his farm. He also raises pigs to sell. In order to build a shelter for his livestock, he is borrowing 5,000 PHP from GDMPC microcredit, of which he has been a member since 2011. He hopes to improve his farm in order to gain more income so he can provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to build a shelter for his livestock

loans.name: Sot's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Sot is a 49-year-old married father with  five dependent children. Rice farming and pineapple planting have been the main sources of his family’s income for 15 years. Sot can earn about 20,000 KHR per day to meet his family’s needs and he manages to save about 14,000 KHR each day for future needs.
 
Sot is the leader of a loan group which has been with VisionFund for two cycles. The group has completely paid back its past loans and Sot has been better able to support his family. Sot will use his portion of the loan to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for his farmland. With this loan, he hopes to grow his rice fruitfully and healthily and also hopes to increase his income and improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for his farm

loans.name: Eugenio

texts.es: Eugenio, de 57 años es un hombre trabajador. Vive en compañía de su esposa Rosalía, con quien tuvo 4 hijos, pero actualmente solo vive uno de ellos en su casa propia. Desde hace 10 años comenzó su camino por la agricultura, al inicio solo sembraba productos agrícolas como papa, oca y demás tubérculos pero conforme paso el tiempo comenzó a incursionar en la crianza de vacas, ovejas, las cuales cuida con mucho esmero y dedicación según comenta, gracias a la venta de leche y elaboración de queso, puede sostener los gastos de su hogar, por lo que es indispensable cuidar de la salud y calidad de sus ganados. Ahora desea aumentar la cantidad de ganados que posee para así poder seguir trabajando sin inconvenientes. Ya que la comercialización de queso ha aumentado considerablemente en su zona y la leche es un ingrediente esencial. Este es su segundo crédito con kiva y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero recibido por está razón se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual . Eugenio, invertirá los S/.300 en la compra de comida balanceada para sus animales.
texts.en: Eugenio, who is 57 years old, is a hard-working man.  He lives with his wife, Rosalía, with whom he had four children.  Currently, only one of his children lives in his house.  Ten years ago, Eugenio started on the agricultural path.  At first, he only grew agricultural products like potatoes, oca and other tubers.  With the passage of time, he started to get into raising cows and sheep, which he tells us that he raises with a lot of care and dedication.  Thanks to sales from the milk and from making cheese, Eugenio can meet his household expenses.  And so it essential that he care for the health and quality of his livestock.  Eugenio now wants to increase the number of livestock he has, so he can keep working without problems.  The sale of cheese has increased considerably in his area and milk is an essential ingredient.  This is Eugenio's second loan with Kiva, and he feels very grateful for the financial help he has received.  That is why he promises to punctually comply with his re-payment plan.  Eugenio will invest the S/.300 (USD $125) in the purchase of feed for his animals.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed.

loans.name: Minh's Group

texts.en:
Minh is 55 years old. She has two adult children. Her husband has cars to rent and earns about 10,000,000 VND per month. Minh helps her husband in his work and has a clothes shop. She has done this job for 20 years, and her income is about 10,000,000 VND. Her family’s total earnings are about 20,000,000 VND per month. 

Minh's dreams are to enlarge her clothes shop, go to many places, and meet more people. However her challenges are a lack of capital to invest in her clothing business and high expenditures for the transportation business. This loan is one step toward realizing her dreams. Minh is a hardworking woman and a passionate businessperson. 

Minh has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2009. In the last cycle, she borrowed 9,632,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,080,000 VND to repair her cars. She always wants to save more money for her family.

Minh's Group also includes Hung. She is 36 years old and has a child. She sells refreshment water. Hung wants to borrow 9,632,000 VND to invest in her business.

loans.use: to repair her cars

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina is 55 years old and married with two children. She lives in Lamao, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. Martina works selling bananas and earns about 3,000 PHP each month. She is a new member of PMPC.

Martina is requesting a loan to purchase more bananas to sell. In the future, she would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more bananas to sell

loans.name: Eudesa

texts.en: Eudesa, a 57-year-old married mother of three children, lives in Taguitic, Kapatagan, Lanao del Norte. To earn a living, she makes nipa to sell. Her husband earns an income from fishing. In 2008, she joined GDMPC. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase nipa leaves to be used for weaving. She plans to expand her business to earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase nipa leaves for weaving

loans.name: Jinrose

texts.en:
Jinrose is 36 years old. She is single with four children who are infants and school-aged. Jinrose lives in Looc, Maria, Siquijor. For the past year, she has raised hogs to earn a living. Jinrose earns 10,000 PHP each month. She is a new member of PMPC.

Jinrose is requesting a 5,000 PHP loan to purchase additional piglets and sacks of feed. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
This is Sharon. Her previous loan helped her not just in her business but also in her family, especially in her child's education. She has been in this business for seven years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Sharon dreams that her business will grow bigger and hopes that her child will finish his studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed for her business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda. She previously accessed a 35,000 PHP loan that she used to buy larger stocks of garlic and biscuits. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in her family's personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy larger stock of garlic and biscuits for her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her family's daily needs and pay for the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Erlinda hopes that her business will grow bigger and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for a larger stock of garlic and biscuits for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicide, pesticide, and seed to grow corn and beans.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! The borrower is 37-year-old Fatmata from Kandeh town Bo. She is married and has four children between the ages of 2 and 22. Her children are attending school. Fatmata runs a palm oil business, where she sells palm oil, beans and peppers. She has been running this business for two years. She works at the business ten hours per day, seven days per week. Fatmata says that the main challenges to her business are that purchasing power is sometime very low, that she doesn’t have many items on her table, and that she lacks funds to expand her business. Fatmata has applied for a loan in order to buy food items, including rice, palm oil and cooking oil, for her food stand. The extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her food stand business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase food items including rice, palm oil and cooking oil for her food stand business.

loans.name: Massah

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! The borrower is 31-year-old Massah from Kandeh town Bo. She is married and has five children between the ages of 6 and 19. Her children are attending school. Massah runs a palm oil business, selling palm oil, nut oil and beans. She has been running this business for eight years. She works at the business ten hours per day and seven days per week. Massah says that the main challenge to her business is that purchasing power is sometimes very low. Massah has applied for a loan in order to buy food items, including gallon containers of palm oil and gari (cassava). The extra income from this loan will allow her to feed her children and increase her business. In the future, she hope to export her goods. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase food items to sell, including gallons of palm oil and gari (cassava).

loans.name: Sarom's Group

texts.en:
Sarom is 43 years old and married with nine children. She and her family live in a village of the Moungkul Borey District in Battambang province. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice and planting vegetables for 20 years, earning about 30,000 KHR per day.

Sarom has been with VisionFund for five cycles and completely repaid her previous loans. She has successfully used the past loans to improve her family’s livelihood. Now she is leading her group to apply for a new loan with VisionFund. She will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and she will use some of the funds to renovate her old house. With this loan, she hopes to grow her crops better and produce higher yields in order to increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Ont's Group

texts.en:
Ont is a 51-year-old married mother of four children who lives in a rural village of the Moung Russey district, Cambodia. Two of her four children are still dependents who are in school. To support her family, Ont has been farming rice and planting pineapple for the past 16 years in her village. She currently earns about 29,000 KHR per day. Ont has received and repaid two previous VisionFund loans. She completely paid back her past loans which helped her better support her family with enough food. 

Ont is the leader of a group loan requesting 1,400,000 KHR for each member. She will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for her farmland. In the future, she hopes to increase her crop yields and sell them for a good price to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase socks, clothing, cosmetic products, etc. to sell

loans.name: Pedy

texts.en:
Pedy is a corn grower at Alcala, Cagayan. He plants and harvests corn to sell. He also hires laborers who help during the planting and harvesting season.  Pedy wants to borrow a loan to invest in his cornfield because he lacks funds to sustain his crops. He is asking for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

He is glad that he is able to sustain the education of his children through his business. Pedy hopes to have a good harvest and maintain a good income for his family's future expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use in farming.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby is married and has three children. She is 62 years old and lives in San Vicente, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Ruby owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of products to earn a living. She has been in this business for more than 20 years. Each month, she earns 9,000 PHP doing this business. 

Ruby requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Ruby has been a member of GDMPC since 2008. In the future, Ruby wants to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
This is Trinidad's fifteenth loan cycle. Her last loan, just like her previous loans, helped a lot in her business. It also helped her family financially, specially in supporting her children's education. Trinidad and her husband, who is a maintenance worker, continue to work to provide for their everyday needs.

Trinidad would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to purchase raw ingredients (such as rice, pork, chicken, and vegetables) and supplies needed in her business. Her profits will help her to sustain her family's daily needs and to meet the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Trinidad dreams of being more successful in her business and hopes to provide a good future to her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, the fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients needed in her business.

loans.name: Rukunyu Tweyimukye Group

texts.en:
Crissy is a member of Rukunyu Tweyimukye Group where members guarantee one another in accessing a loan. She is a 46-year-old married woman living in Kamwenge, Uganda. She deals in a produce business which she started nine years ago. Her dream is to ensure that her family gets all their basic needs since she is the breadwinner.

Unpredictable weather changes, especially the dry season and price fluctuations, are her major challenges, while her business plan is to own a food store that can sustainably supply her customers all year round. Crissy is requesting a loan to buy produce such as maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: to buy produce such as maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion is 53 years old, married to Samuel, and she manages a half-hectare of cornfield. She and her spouse have been patiently growing corn to sell for over ten years now. 

She wanted to increase her crops, but she needs enough capital to sustain it with a sufficient supply of pesticides and herbicides. Because of this she is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy pesticides and herbicides for the maintenance of the cornfield. 

Consolacion promises to pay back her loan in full and will keep developing her crop production to achieve profits for the overall welfare of her family.

loans.use: to buy pesticides and herbicides.

loans.name: Emmanuel Vital

texts.en:
This loan will allow Emmanuel to develop his credit and to create a business website to increase visibility online.

Born and raised in Miami, Emmanuel is an entrepreneur at heart. He has owned and operated "First Concept Wireless", a full service wireless store, since 2005. While his store provides retail of cell phones, along with phone accessories, such as headsets and phone cases, he also does phone repair, which is what originally brought him into the business. “I started working on all my friends’ phones from my house, and my family encouraged me to open my own store. It truly became my passion. I love what I do!” proclaims Emmanuel.

His business employs seven additional people besides his sister, who assists in managing the business. His vision for the future is to have multiple stores in the Miami area and to provide the best price with great service. He personally strives for a well-rounded and balanced life.

loans.use: to create a business website to increase visibility online

loans.name: Melvin

texts.en: Melvin is a farmer and a father of three. He is 42 years old and married. Melvin plants and harvests corn to sell. He would like to keep achieving good crops and income for his family.  At the moment he is in need of additional capital of P10,000 that he will use to buy fertilizers and insecticides to use in farming. He hopes that someday through his business he can provide a better way of living for his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a hardworking married woman living in Masindi, Uganda. She operates a retail shop where she sells general merchandise. With the profits, she has been able to buy land and start the construction of her residential house. Her dreams are to complete her house and educate her children up to the University, although she is faced with problems of price fluctuation and lack of enough capital. Jane is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en:
Living a wooden house in the Kror Kor district of Pursat province, Thy is 38 years old and married with three children. The main source of her family’s income is rice farming. Thy has been a rice farmer for almost ten years and currently earns about 15,000 KHR per day. 

Thy is the leader of a group loan. This is her first loan request with VisionFund and she will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to increase her crop yield and sell it for a good price to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta is a 64-year-old widowed mother of three living in Aurora, Zambo del Sur, Philippines. She has been operating her own retail store from her home for many years. Alberta joined GDMPC in 2011.

Alberta is requesting a 5,000 PHP loan to purchase additional goods to sell. In the future, she plans to repair her store's native roof and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase goods to sell

loans.name: Ry's Group

texts.en:
Ry is 50 years old and married with five kids. She lives with her husband in a rural village of the Ponhea Krek district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Ry and her husband earn a living through planting rice on a one-hectare plot of farmland. Sometimes, her husband works for others for a fee. Together, they can earn about 10,000 KHR per day and manage to save about 5,000 KHR each day after offsetting expenses.

Ry is the leader of a two-member loan group that is requesting its first loan with VisionFund. She will use her portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland. Ry hopes her loan will enable her to earn more income from her current business to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 49-year-old hardworking mother with two school-going children living in Masindi, Uganda. She runs a bar and a lodge business. With the proceeds she has been able to educate her children and has also started building a residential house for the family. Her dream is to complete her house. Her major challenges are high competition and the lack of enough capital. Betty is requesting a loan to buy construction materials such as cement and sand to complete her house.

loans.use: to buy construction materials such as cement and sand to complete her house.

loans.name: Karina

texts.es: Karina tiene 40 años, está casada, y vive en su casa propia con sus dos hijos, y está esperando un tercer hijo. Karina se dedica la venta de comidas regionales como pollo asado, guisos, entre otros los cuales vende al frente de su hogar. Lleva 4 años en este negocio y cuenta con la ayuda de su hija para la preparación de sus comidas. Le gusta su negocio ya que le permite tener un ingreso económico con el cual puede ayudar con los gastos de su hogar, tiene planes de seguir con su negocio y mantenerlo estable, por esta razón desea comprar mejores sillas y mesas para brindar mayor comodidad a sus clientes. En este préstamo con Kiva, Karina agradece la oportunidad y confianza que ponen en ella para recibir éste crédito, y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de manera puntual. El monto solicitado de S/. 3000 lo invertirá en la compra de ingredientes para la preparación de sus comidas tales como arroz, aceites, papas, aceites, condimentos, verduras y otros.
texts.en:
Karina, age 40, is married.  She lives in her own house with her two children, and she is expecting her third child.  Karina sells regional food like roasted chicken and stews, among others.  She sells the food in front of her house.  She has been in this business for four years, and her daughter helps her prepare the food.

She likes her business because it allows her to have an income with which she is able to help with the household expenses.  She has plans to continue with her business and to keep it stable.  That is the reason she wishes to buy better tables and chairs to provide her customers with greater comfort.

Karina is grateful for the opportunity and the trust placed in her with this Kiva loan.  She pledges to make her payments punctually.  She will use the requested 3,000 soles to buy ingredients to make the food.  She will buy things like rice, potatoes, cooking oil, condiments, vegetables, and others.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making food.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her son's livestock business.

loans.name: Sadress

texts.en:
Sadress is a 33-year-old married woman with four children living in Kasese, Uganda. With a desire to educate her children, she decided to trade cassava flour, a business that she has done for a year. She hopes to have a wholesale business, despite challenges of bad weather and limited capital. 

Sadress will use the loan to buy more cassava flour to sell.

loans.use: to buy more cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Calixto

texts.en:
